Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is based on one study and there are other studies that question the findings.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the temperature drop during the week after 9/11 was solely due to the absence of jet vapor trails, without considering other factors that may have contributed to the temperature change.
Exist alternative explanation: Other studies suggest that the temperature change observed during the three-day flying hiatus after 9/11 may have been a coincidence and not directly caused by the absence of contrails.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times as it relies on past news stories and may not have taken into account more recent research on the topic.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the temperature drop after 9/11 was solely caused by the absence of commercial airplanes, without considering other factors that may have influenced the temperature change.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the impact of the absence of jet vapor trails on the temperature change, as other studies suggest that the effect may have been minimal or coincidental.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the provided claim.
